title: 第1章 绯红
baseline_translation:
Pain!
Such pain!
My head hurts so much!
The bizarre and murmuring dreams shattered in an instant, and as Zhou Mingrui lay in a deep sleep, he felt an intense throbbing pain in his head, as if struck by a club, no, more like a sharp object piercing his temples and stirring within!

Hiss... groggily, Zhou Mingrui tried to turn over, to cover his head, to sit up, but he couldn’t move a muscle, as if his body had lost control.

It seems I haven’t truly woken up yet, still in a dream... I might even experience that feeling of thinking I’m awake but am still asleep... Zhou Mingrui, who wasn’t unfamiliar with such scenarios, strained his will, desperately trying to break free from the darkness and the illusions.

But in the half-sleep state, his will felt as elusive as smoke, hard to grasp or contain. No matter how hard he tried, his thoughts kept drifting, random thoughts surfacing.

What on earth could cause such a sudden, severe headache in the dead of night?

Could it be a hemorrhage or something like that?

Damn it, am I about to die young?

Wake up! Wake up!

Hmm, it seems less painful than before? But there’s still this dull ache, like a dull knife slowly carving into my brain...

I can’t fall back asleep now; how will I get to work tomorrow?

Thinking about work? With a real headache, of course, I should take a sick day! No need to worry about my boss nagging me!

Thinking like this, it actually doesn’t sound so bad, hehe, stealing a half-day of freedom!

Round after round of sharp pain allowed Zhou Mingrui to gradually accumulate a faint, illusory strength. Finally, he pushed himself up with a surge of effort, opening his eyes wide and completely shaking off the half-conscious state.

His vision was blurry at first, then it clouded with a faint crimson hue. As his gaze cleared, he saw a rustic wooden desk before him, with an open notebook lying in the center. The paper was rough and yellowed, and a strange line of text was written at the top in dark, dripping ink that stood out vividly.

To the left of the notebook, near the edge of the desk, sat a stack of neatly arranged books, probably seven or eight of them. To their right, on the wall, were gray-white pipes connected to a wall lamp. This lamp had a distinctly Western classical style, about half the size of a human head. The inner layer was transparent glass, and the outer layer was framed by black metal grilles.

Beneath the lamp, a black inkwell was surrounded by a faint reddish glow, its surface etched with blurry angelic patterns.

Before the notebook, on the right side, rested a dark steel pen with a rounded belly, its tip shimmering with a faint light. The pen cap lay beside a yellow-brass revolver.

A revolver? Zhou Mingrui froze, his entire body stunned. The scene before him was utterly unfamiliar, nothing like his own room!

Overwhelmed and bewildered, he noticed that the desk, the notebook, the inkwell, and even the revolver were all veiled in a layer of crimson "gauze"—the light filtering in from outside.

Without thinking, he raised his head and slowly shifted his gaze upward:

In the air, a dark "velvet curtain" hung, upon which a blood-red full moon hung high, casting a serene light.

This... Zhou Mingrui was overcome by a strange fear. He abruptly stood up, but his legs hadn’t fully straightened when another sharp pain struck, stealing his strength and causing him to lose balance. His backside slammed hard against the hard wood of the chair.

*Crack!*

The pain didn’t deter him; he placed his hands on the desk and stood up again, turning his body frantically to survey his surroundings.

This was a small room with two brown doors on either side. Opposite the wall was a wooden bunk bed. Between the left door and the bunk bed stood a cabinet with an upper section that opened and five drawers below. At eye level on the cabinet, gray-white pipes were embedded in the wall, connecting to a strange mechanical device with some exposed gears and bearings.

Near the right wall, by the desk, was a pile of coal-burning stoves and kitchen utensils like pots and pans. Beyond the right door was a cracked穿衣镜 with a simple wooden base.

As he scanned the room, Zhou Mingrui caught a glimpse of himself in the mirror: black hair, brown eyes, wearing a flaxen shirt, thin build, average features with deep contours...

This... Zhou Mingrui gasped, his heart filled with a sense of helplessness and confusion.

The revolver, the Western classical decor, and that crimson moon unlike Earth’s—all pointed to something!

Did I... did I travel? Zhou Mingrui’s mouth slowly opened.

He’d grown up reading online novels and often fantasized about such things, but when it actually happened, he found it hard to accept.

This must be the saying, "Ye Gong’s love of dragons," Zhou Mingrui sarcastically remarked to himself after a minute or so.

If not for the persistent pain keeping his mind sharp, he might have believed he was still dreaming.

Calm down, calm down, calm down... Taking several deep breaths, Zhou Mingrui tried to steady himself.

Just then, as his mind and body harmonized, fragments of memory abruptly surfaced and slowly unfolded in his mind!

Cai Lian. Mo Lei Ti, from the northern continent’s Luon Kingdom, Aihua County, Tinggu City. A recent graduate from the History Department of Huoyi University...

His father was a Royal Army Sergeant, who sacrificed himself in a colonial conflict on the southern continent. The compensation money allowed Cai Lian to attend a private grammar school, laying the foundation for his university education...

His mother, a devotee of the Night Goddess, passed away the year he passed the Huoyi University entrance exam...

He had an older brother and a younger sister, living together in a two-bedroom apartment...

The family wasn’t wealthy, perhaps even struggling. They relied on his older brother, who worked as an office clerk at an import-export company...

As a history graduate, Cai Lian had mastered the ancient Fasack language, said to be the source of all northern continent scripts, as well as the Hermes Text—often found in ancient tombs, related to祭祀 and祈祷...

Hermes Text? Zhou Mingrui’s heart skipped a beat. He pressed his aching temples and looked at the open notebook on the desk. The strange text on the yellowed paper began to shift from strange to familiar, from unfamiliar to recognizable.

This was written in the Hermes Text!

The deeply inked words read:

"All will die, including me."

Hiss! Zhou Mingrui was unnerved, instinctively leaning back, trying to distance himself from the notebook and those words.

He felt weak, nearly falling, so he grabbed the desk edge, his body trembling. The air around him seemed agitated, and faint whispers echoed in his ears, like listening to scary stories as a child.

Shaking his head, he realized it was just a hallucination. He steadied himself and looked away from the notebook, taking deep breaths.

His gaze then fell on the revolver gleaming with brass. A question suddenly popped into his mind.

"With Cai Lian’s financial situation, how could he afford a gun?"

Zhou Mingrui frowned.

As he pondered, he noticed a half-finger print of red on the edge of the desk, darker than the moonlight, thicker than the "gauze."

It was a bloodstain!

"Bloodstain?" Zhou Mingrui instinctively turned his right hand, which had been holding the desk edge, and looked down. His palm and fingers were covered in blood.

At the same time, the throbbing pain in his head continued, slightly less intense but persistent.

"Did I hit my head?" Zhou Mingrui wondered, turning his body and heading towards the cracked穿衣镜.

After a few steps, he saw a medium-built man with black hair, brown eyes, and a scholarly air clearly reflected in the mirror.

Is this me, Cai Lian. Mo Lei Ti?

Zhou Mingrui froze, partly because the lighting was dim in the middle of the night, so he couldn’t see clearly. He stepped closer, almost about to bump into the mirror.

Under the faint, gauzy moonlight, he tilted his head to check the side of his forehead.

The mirror reflected him clearly: a狰狞 wound marred his temple, with burn marks around the edges, and blood smeared all around.

title: 第2章 情况
baseline_translation:
**Chapter 2: The Situation**

*Thump, thump, thump!*

Zhou Mingri stumbled backward several steps, nearly tripping over his own feet, his heart pounding like a drum. The figure reflected in the mirror before him wasn’t himself—it looked more like a dried-up corpse. A man with such grievous injuries could not possibly be alive!

He tilted his head to the side, unable to believe what he was seeing, and checked the other side of the mirror. Even with the increased distance and slightly blurred reflection, the贯穿 wound and the crimson bloodstains were unmistakable.

“Wha—”

Zhou Mingri took a deep breath, forcing himself to calm down. He reached out and pressed his hand firmly against his left chest, feeling the powerful, rapid, yet vital beat of his heart. Then, he touched the exposed skin, noting a faint coolness beneath a warm, flowing heat. He crouched down, testing the flexibility of his knees, and then stood up again, the initial panic subsiding slightly.

“What’s going on?” He frowned, his voice low as he decided to carefully examine the wound on his head once more.

Taking two steps forward, he paused suddenly. The light from the blood moon outside was too dim to allow for a thorough inspection. A fragment of memory surged to the forefront, and Zhou Mingri turned his head toward the wall lamp beside his desk, encased in gray pipes and metal grilles.

This was the current mainstream gas lamp, with a stable flame and excellent illumination. Given the circumstances of his brother, Kaelen Morty, it was unlikely that their family could even afford an oil lamp, let alone a gas lamp. Candles were the expected standard for their social standing. However, four years prior, while Zhou Mingri had stayed up late studying for the Hoy University entrance exams, his brother, Ban Shen, had insisted on installing the gas line. Ban Shen, a literate and employed man, was far from reckless or impulsive; he had convinced their landlord by arguing that gas lines would elevate the apartment’s prestige and make it more rentable in the future. Zhou Mingri himself had secured a nearly cost-price gas lamp through his job at an import-export company, all without borrowing money, using only his savings.

The memory fragment flickered past, and Zhou Mingri returned to his desk. He opened the gas valve and twisted the lamp switch. *Click, click, click.* But the expected light did not appear. He twisted the switch again, *click, click, click,* but the gas lamp remained dim.

“Hmm…” He withdrew his hand, pressed his left temple, and drew upon the fragmented memory, searching for the cause of the issue.

After a few seconds, he turned his body and walked over to the door, heading toward the mechanical device on the wall next to it, connected by the same gray pipes. It was a gas meter!

Glancing at the exposed gears and bearings, Zhou Mingri reached into his trouser pocket and pulled out a coin. It was a dull yellow, with a sheen of copper, featuring a crowned man’s portrait on one side and the letter “1” surrounded by wheat stalks on the other. Zhou Mingri knew this was the basic currency of the Luun Kingdom, called a copper penny. One penny had roughly the purchasing power of three or four yuan before his arrival in this world. Pennies were available in denominations of five, half, and quarter pennies, but the system was still crude. People often had to round up to purchase items.

After flipping the King George III penny in his fingers a few times, Zhou Mingri pinched it and inserted it into the vertical, slit-like “mouth” of the gas meter.

*Clatter, clatter!*

As the penny fell into the meter, the sound of gears engaging echoed, playing a short, melodious mechanical tune.

Zhou Mingri stared for a few seconds, then returned to his desk and twisted the gas lamp switch again.

*Click, click, click.* *Pop!*

A flame sprang to life, quickly growing larger. Bright light filled the lampshade and spilled through the glass, casting a warm glow over the room.

The darkness receded abruptly, the blood moon receding from the windows. Zhou Mingri felt a strange sense of reassurance. He quickly walked to the mirror.

This time, he examined his temple carefully, scrutinizing every detail. After comparing several times, he noticed that apart from the initial bloodstains, the gruesome wound hadn’t oozed any more liquid. It seemed to have been expertly stopped and bandaged. Meanwhile, the slowly pulsating gray brain and the visibly growing flesh around the wound signaled the beginning of the healing process. It might take anywhere from thirty to forty minutes, or perhaps two or three hours, but eventually, only faint traces would remain.

“Is it the healing effect from the transmigration?” Zhou Mingri raised the corner of his mouth in a slight smirk, whispering to himself.

He let out a long sigh. Regardless of the cause, he was still alive!

Centering himself, he pulled out a small bar of soap from a drawer and took a worn towel hanging beside the cabinet. He then opened the door and headed to the second-floor communal bathroom for the tenants.

Hmm, the blood on his head needed to be cleaned up. He didn’t want to look like a crime scene, scaring himself one thing, but scaring his sister, Melissa, who had to get up early tomorrow, would be a disaster.

The hallway outside was pitch black, only the faint crimson moonlight filtering through the end window barely outlining the shapes of objects, making them resemble countless monster eyes silently watching the living in the depths of the night.

Zhou Mingri moved quietly, his heart pounding nervously as he approached the bathroom.

Once inside, the moonlight was stronger, illuminating everything clearly. He stood before the sink and turned on the faucet.

*Whoosh, whoosh, whoosh.*

The sound of running water suddenly reminded him of their landlord, Mr. Franz. Because water fees were included in the rent, the short, stout, thin, and always-dapper Mr. Franz, who wore a bowler hat, a waistcoat, and a black suit, frequently inspected the bathrooms, listening for the sound of running water.

If the noise was too loud, Mr. Franz would disregard his gentlemanly demeanor, furiously brandish his walking stick, and shout, “Damn thieves!” “Waste is shameful!” “I’ll remember you!” “If I catch you doing this again, you’ll leave with your dirty belongings!” “Trust me, this is the most cost-effective apartment in Tingrin City. You won’t find a more generous landlord than me!”

Shaking off the thought, Zhou Mingri wet the towel and began wiping the blood off his face, repeatedly.

After checking himself in the dilapidated bathroom mirror, confirming that only the gruesome wound and pale face remained, Zhou Mingri felt a bit lighter. He then removed his linen shirt and used the soap to scrub the bloodstains.

Just then, his brow furrowed as a new worry surfaced: The wound was dramatic, the bloodstains numerous. Besides himself, there should be traces in the room!

After a few minutes, Zhou Mingri finished cleaning his shirt and hurried back home with the wet towel. He first wiped the bloodstains from his hands on the desk, then, relying on the gas lamp’s light, searched for any other traces.

His search revealed numerous blood splatters on the floor and under the desk, and near the left wall, he found a shiny bullet casing.

“…Did he shoot himself in the head with a revolver?” The clues suddenly connected, and Zhou Mingri guessed the cause of Kaelen’s death.

He didn’t rush to verify it immediately. First, he meticulously cleaned the bloodstains, tidied up the “crime scene,” and then retrieved the bullet casing, returning to the desk. He opened the revolver’s cylinder and dumped out the bullets inside.

*Click, click, click.* There were five bullets and one empty casing, all gleaming with brass.

“Indeed…” Zhou Mingri glanced at the empty casing, nodding slightly as he carefully reloaded the bullets into the cylinder.

His gaze shifted left to the notebook lying open, where the words “Everyone will die, including me” were written. More questions flooded his mind.

Where did the gun come from?

Was it a suicide or a staged suicide?

What kind of trouble could a history graduate from a commoner family get into?

How did this method of suicide leave so little blood? Was it because he had arrived in time, possessing some kind of healing ability?

He pondered for a moment, then changed into another linen shirt and sat down in his chair, focusing on more pressing matters.

Kaelen’s situation wasn’t the main concern right now. The real issue was figuring out why he had transmigrated and whether he could return.

His parents, relatives, close friends, the vibrant online world, the variety of delicious food… All of these fueled his desperate desire to go back.

*Click, click, click…*

Zhou Mingri absentmindedly spun the revolver’s cylinder in his right hand, then recocked it, repeating the motion.

“Hmm, things haven’t been much different lately, except for being a bit unlucky. How did I suddenly transmigrate without any warning?”

“Unlucky… Wait, I performed a luck-changing ritual before dinner tonight!”

A bolt of lightning struck through Zhou Mingri’s mind, illuminating the foggy memories he had been trying to suppress.

As a self-proclaimed “somewhat knowledgeable” expert in keyboard politics, history, economics, biology, and folklore, he was often teased by his friends for being “only somewhat knowledgeable” in each.

Among these was the practice of feng shui and divination.

Last year, on a trip back home, he had stumbled upon an old, bound book titled “Secrets of Qin and Han Alchemy and Divination Techniques” at a used book stall. Finding it intriguing and thinking it would help him appear more knowledgeable online, he had bought it. Unfortunately, his interest faded quickly; the vertical text was difficult to read, and he only flipped through the beginning before abandoning the book in a corner.

Now, after a string of bad luck—losing his phone, a client backing out, a work mistake—when misfortunes seemed to come one after another, he had randomly remembered the luck-changing ritual mentioned at the start of the book. The ritual required nothing but basic materials.

With no cost involved, he had retrieved the book and performed the ritual before dinner. But nothing had happened at the time.

Yet, that night, he had transmigrated!

He had *transmigrated*!

“It’s possible that ritual was the cause… Well, I’ll try it here tomorrow. If it really was that, then there’s hope I can return!”

Zhou Mingri stopped spinning the revolver and sat up straight.

No matter what, he had to try!

Even a dead horse was worth treating as if it were still alive!

title: 第3章 梅丽莎
baseline_translation:
**Chapter 3: Melissa**

With the plan confirmed, Zhou Mingrui found his anchor, and the fear, hesitation, and unease that had cornered themselves were finally pushed aside. Only then did he have the mental space to carefully examine the fragmented memories left by Cullen.

Habituating himself, Zhou Mingrui stood up, shut off the pipe valve, watched the wall lamp fade and extinguish, then sat back down. His fingers unconsciously stroked the brass cylinder of the revolver as he pressed his temple, quietly "tasting" the aftermath in the crimson-darkened gloom, like the most attentive audience in a cinema.

Possibly influenced by the bullet passing through him, Cullen's memories were like shattered glass – not only disjointed, but many parts were conspicuously missing. For instance, the origin of the finely crafted revolver, whether it was a suicide or murder, and the meaning behind the notebook entry "Everyone dies, including me." He also wondered if he had participated in any strange events in the days leading up to the incident.

Not just these specific recollections were fragmented and incomplete; even the acquired knowledge was deficient. In his current state, Zhou Mingrui believed that if Cullen were to return to university, he probably wouldn't graduate. Despite having only been away from campus for a few days and maintaining a rigorous self-discipline.

_"Two days later, I have to attend the history department interview at Tinggan University..."_

_"The Ruin Kingdom's universities have a tradition of not directly hiring graduates... The mentor provided recommendation letters for both Tinggan University and Bekland University..."_

...

Lost in this silent "viewing," Zhou Mingrui didn't notice the red moon sinking in the west, gradually descending until a faint light appeared in the east, dyeing the horizon gold. Inside the room, a stir was heard, followed quickly by footsteps approaching the isolation door.

_"Melissa woke up... She's as punctual as ever."_ Zhou Mingrui offered a subtle smile, influenced by Cullen's memories, seeing Melissa as if she were his own younger sister.

But I don't actually have a younger sister... He immediately muttered a self-deprecating remark.

Melissa was different from both Cullen and Benson. Her primary education wasn't completed at the Night女神 Church's Sunday School. By the time she reached school age, the Ruin Kingdom had enacted the "Elementary Education Act," establishing a low-to-middle education committee and allocating specific funding to increase investment.

Within three years, following the integration of numerous church-run schools, a multitude of public elementary schools were established. Strictly adhering to the principle of religious neutrality, they avoided entanglement in disputes involving the Storm Lord, Night女神, and the Church of Steam and Machinery.

Compared to the Sunday Schools costing just one penny per week, the public elementary schools' tuition of three pence weekly seemed quite expensive. However, the former only operated once a week on Sundays, while the latter required six full days of schooling per week. Overall, the Sunday School's price was nearly free.

Melissa, unlike most girls, had always been fascinated by gears, springs, and bearings, aspiring to become a steam mechanic. Aware of the educational disadvantage she herself had faced, her elder brother Benson, who understood the importance of education, supported Melissa's dream much like he had Cullen's university education. After all, Tinggan Technical School was only considered secondary education, so further schooling at a grammar school or public school wasn't necessary.

Last July, at fifteen years old, Melissa passed the entrance examination and, as wished, became a student in the Steam and Mechanics department at Tinggan Technical School, with the weekly tuition increasing to nine pence.

Around the same time, however, the company Benson worked for, an import-export firm, suffered a significant decline in both profits and business volume due to the Southlands' instability. This forced the company to lay off over a third of its staff. To keep his job and maintain their livelihood, Benson could only accept heavier workloads, often requiring overtime or frequent business trips to harsh environments, just like these past few days.

Cullen hadn't failed to consider helping his brother shoulder the burden, but as a commoner and a product of a regular grammar school, he felt acutely aware of his shortcomings from the moment he entered university. For instance, Old Fasak, the foundational language of the North大陸's nations, was a subject taught from childhood to noble heirs and wealthy children. Cullen only encountered it for the first time during university.

Similar deficiencies were widespread. Cullen had to push himself relentlessly, often pulling all-nighters, to勉强 keep up and graduate with average grades.

The memories of his brother and sister swirled in Zhou Mingrui's mind, until the turning of the handle brought him back to reality. He realized he was still holding a revolver in his hand.

This was a semi-controlled item!

It could scare a child!

And what about the wound on his head!

Just as Melissa was about to step out, Zhou Mingrui pressed his temple and hastily pulled open the desk drawer, tossing the revolver inside with a *clunk*.

_"What's wrong?"_ Melissa asked, her gaze filled with curiosity.

Though not well-nourished, she was still at the peak of her youth. Her face, though thin and slightly pale, retained a healthy glow, radiating a youthful spirit.

Meeting her brown eyes fixedly upon him, Zhou Mingrui forced calm, picking up the items near his hand, then smoothly closed the drawer, concealing the revolver. The sensation of his fingers on his temple confirmed that the wound had healed!

From the drawer, he pulled out a silver-white pocket watch adorned with vine and leaf patterns. Pressing the top gently opened the cover.

It was the most valuable item left by their father, the Royal Army Sergeant, but as a second-hand piece, it inevitably had issues. Even after repairs by a watchmaker, it remained unreliable, often causing embarrassment for Benson, who liked wearing it to elevate his status. Eventually, it was left behind in the family home.

One cannot deny that Melissa might truly possess mechanical talent. After mastering the theoretical knowledge, she began experimenting with the tools from Tinggan Technical School to fix the pocket watch. Recently, she even claimed to have successfully repaired it!

As the cover snapped open, Zhou Mingrui noticed the second hand was stuck. He instinctively twisted the crown, hoping to wind the mechanism, but no click of a tightened mainspring echoed, and the second hand remained motionless.

_"Seems like it broke again."_ He said, making conversation with his sister.

Melissa glanced at him without expression, then quickly approached, snatching the pocket watch.

Standing still, she first pulled up the crown's button, twisting it only a few turns before the ticking sound of the second hand began.

Normally, pulling the crown shouldn't advance the time... Zhou Mingrui's expression froze.

At that moment, the distant cathedral bells rang out, six deep, resonant chimes.

Melissa listened intently, then pushed the crown higher, twisting it continuously to set the time.

_"Done."_ She stated briefly, without any emotion, then pushed the crown back, handing the watch to Zhou Mingrui.

Zhou Mingrui offered a尴尬而不失礼貌的 smile in return.

Melissa cast one last look at her brother, turned, and walked towards the cabinet, picking up her toothbrush, towel, and other items before pulling the door open to head to the shared restroom.

_"Was her expression earlier a mix of嫌弃 and resignation?"_

_"The look of affection towards a disabled brother?"_

Zhou Mingrui shook his head, chuckling softly. He snapped the cover shut with a *click*, then opened it again with a *pop*.

Engaging in this repetitive motion, his thoughts wandered to a question.

Without a silencer, Cullen's suicide – let's call it suicide for now – must have made considerable noise. Yet Melissa, separated by only a wall, hadn't noticed a thing.

Was she too deeply asleep? Or was the act of Cullen's suicide inherently strange?

*Click*, open. *Tap*, close... Melissa returned from her wash, witnessing her brother's unconscious, repetitive opening and closing of the watch cover.

Her gaze once again clouded with resignation. Her voice sweet as honey, she said:

_"Cullen, take out the remaining bread. Remember to buy fresh ones today. Also, some meat and peas. You're heading to the interview soon, so I'll make you pea stew with lamb."_

As she spoke, she pulled the stove from the corner, lit a fire with the remaining embers, and boiled a pot of water.

Just before it boiled, she opened the bottom drawer of the cabinet, carefully pulling out a can of inferior tea leaves. Sprinkling about ten leaves into the pot, she pretended it was genuine tea.

Pouring two large cups, Melissa and Zhou Mingrui shared two black rye breads with the tea.

No wood shavings mixed in, not too much麸质, but still... not very good. Zhou Mingrui, weakened and hungry, forced himself to swallow the breads, criticizing internally while relying on the tea.

A few minutes later, Melissa finished, tidied her black hair, and looked at Zhou Mingrui.

_"Remember to buy new bread, just eight pounds. It's hot, so too much will spoil. Also, lamb and peas. Don't forget!"_

Typical sibling care for a bookworm, even if she emphasized it... Zhou Mingrui smiled and nodded.

_"I will."_

Regarding the Ruin Kingdom's pound, Zhou Mingrui, comparing it to Cullen's memory of the meat measurement and his own understanding, estimated it to be roughly equivalent to what he was used to, about half a kilogram.

Melissa said no more, got up, tidied up, packed the last bread for lunch, put on her late mother's worn-out veil, and picked up her own knapsack, prepared with books, stationery, and other school supplies, ready to leave.

Today wasn't Sunday; she had to attend school for the whole day.

Walking from this apartment to Tinggan Technical School took about fifty minutes. There were public horse-drawn carriages, costing one penny per kilometer, with a maximum of four pence within the city limits and six pence for the suburbs. To save money, Melissa always left early and walked.

Just as she opened the door, she paused, half-turning.

_"Cullen, don't buy too much lamb and peas. Benson might not be back until Sunday. Also, just eight pounds of bread."_

_"Alright, alright."_ Zhou Mingrui replied helplessly.

At the same time, he silently repeated the word "Sunday" several times in his mind.

In the North大陸, the year is divided into twelve months, ranging from 365 to 366 days. A week still consists of seven days.

The former is a result of astronomical observation, making Zhou Mingrui suspect this might be a parallel world. The latter stems from religion, as the North大陸 recognizes seven major deities: Eternal Sun, Lord of Storms, God of Knowledge and Wisdom, Night女神, Goddess of the Earth, God of War, and God of Steam and Machinery.

Watching Melissa close the door and leave, Zhou Mingrui let out a sigh, quickly shifting his focus back to the ritual transfer.

Sorry, I truly wish to go home...

title: 第4章 占卜
baseline_translation:
**Chapter 4: Divination**

He sank back into his chair. It wasn't until the distant church bell tolled seven times, echoing through the air, that Zhou Mingri finally rose slowly, walked over to the cabinet, and took out his clothes.

A black waistcoat, trousers that fit snugly around the ankles, a low-crowned top hat, and a faint scholarly air combined to make Zhou Mingri feel as if he were watching a Victorian-era British drama when he looked at himself in the mirror.

"I'm not going for an interview," he muttered to himself, shaking his head and chuckling at his own expense. "I'm just buying some groceries to prepare for a ritual to change my fortune..."

Clayen's eagerness for the upcoming interview had become so ingrained in him that it had turned into an instinct. Whenever his focus wavered, he unconsciously slipped into this one set of decent attire.

He took a deep breath, removed the suit and waistcoat, and put on an old, tawny-brown coat. His headwear also changed, now a matching low-crowned felt hat.

After tidying himself up, he walked over to the bunk bed, lifted the mat on top, and reached down through an inconspicuous tear in the fabric at the bottom to search the hidden compartment.

When his right hand pulled back, a roll of banknotes was in his palm, about seven notes in total, their color a dark, almost bluish-green.

This was all that Banse had saved up to that point, including the living expenses for these past three days. There were only two five-syllar notes among them, the rest being one-syllar bills.

In the currency system of the Ruin Kingdom, the Syllar was the second tier, originating from ancient silver coins. One Syllar was equal to twelve copper pennies, and there were one-syllar and five-syllar denominations.

At the top of the monetary scale were Gold Pounds, also paper notes but backed by gold and directly linked to it. One Gold Pound was equivalent to twenty Syllars, with denominations of one, five, and ten.

Zhou Mingri unfolded the notes, catching a faint, peculiar scent of special ink.

This was the smell of money.

Perhaps it was influenced by fragments of Clayen's memories, or maybe it was simply his unchanging desire for wealth, but at that moment, Zhou Mingri found himself loving these little notes.

Look, the designs on them were so exquisite that even King George III, with his trimmed beard and stern demeanor, seemed endearing...

Look, the watermark visible through the sunlight was so tempting, and the carefully designed anti-counterfeiting labels made it stand out distinctly from its fake counterparts!

Appreciating them for nearly half a minute, Zhou Mingri pulled out two one-syllar notes, rolled the remaining ones back up, and tucked them back into the hidden compartment under the mat.

He smoothed out the fabric around the tear, neatly folded the two one-syllar notes, and put them in the left pocket of his tawny-brown coat. The few pennies in his trouser pocket were kept separate.

With that done, he slipped the key into his right pocket, picked up the large brown paper bag, and hurried towards the door.

Tap-tap, the footsteps quickened then slowed, finally coming to a halt.

Zhou Mingri stood by the door, his brow furrowed without him even realizing it.

Clayen's suicide left many questions unanswered. If he just went out like this, would he encounter some "accident"?

After pondering for a moment, Zhou Mingri returned to the desk, opened a drawer, and took out a revolver, its brass gleaming.

This was the only defensive weapon he could think of, and a powerful one at that!

Although he had never practiced shooting, just pulling out this pistol should be enough to intimidate someone!

He ran his fingers over the cold metal cylinder, then stuffed the gun into the pocket with the money, clenching the banknotes in his palm and pressing firmly on the grip, perfectly concealing it.

A sense of security washed over him. Suddenly, a worry surfaced in his mind:

"Won't I accidentally fire it?"

As thoughts raced through his mind, Zhou Mingri quickly found a solution. He drew the pistol, spun the cylinder to the left, positioning the chamber that was left empty due to "suicide" into the ready position, then snapped it shut with a click.

This way, even if there was an accidental discharge, it would be a "dud"!

After reinserting the gun, Zhou Mingri kept his left hand in the pocket, no longer taking it out.

He patted his hat with his right hand and opened the door, stepping out with a resounding *thump*.

The corridor was still dimly lit during the day, with limited sunlight filtering through the end windows. Zhou Mingri hurried down the stairs, left the apartment, and only then felt the warmth and brightness of the outside.

Although it was near July, the height of summer, Tynemouth, located in the northern part of the Ruin Kingdom, had a unique climate. The highest temperature in a year barely reached what was considered 30 degrees Celsius on Earth. The mornings were cool, but some parts of the streets were littered with dirty water and discarded trash. In Clayen's memories, such scenes were not uncommon in areas inhabited by the lower-income classes, even if they had sewers, because of the high population density and the realities of their lives.

"Come on, come on, delicious pan-fried meat and fish!"  
"Fresh oysters, hot and fresh, drink a bowl in the morning and you'll be energized all day!"  
"Fresh fish from the port, just five pennies a piece!"  
"Small scones, Mackerel soup with ginger beer!"  
"Scallops, scallops, scallops!"  
"Fresh vegetables just picked from the farms outside the city, cheap and fresh!"  

...

Street vendors selling vegetables, fruits, and prepared foods shouted out their pitches, calling out to the hurried passersby. Some would stop to carefully compare and choose, while others would grow impatient and wave them away, as they hadn't secured any work yet for the day.

Zhou Mingri smelled a mixture of foul and enticing odors in the air, his left hand firmly gripping the gun handle, clutching the banknotes in his palm, and his right hand pressing down on his round-crowned felt hat. He bent his head slightly, lowered his gaze, and pushed through the bustling street.

Thieves thrived in crowded places, especially in this district where many half-unemployed people did odd jobs, and hungry children were often used as errand runners.

As they walked, when the density of the crowd returned to normal, Zhou Mingri straightened his back, lifted his head, and looked around the street.

A street musician was playing the accordion nearby, his melody sometimes melancholic, sometimes passionate.

Beside him, a crowd had gathered around some ragged children whose faces were蜡黄 (wan) due to malnutrition.

They listened to the music, moved to the rhythm, and instinctively twisted their bodies, dancing their own improvised steps. Their faces were filled with joy, as if they were little princes or angels.

A woman with a blank expression walked past, her skirt dirty, her skin dull. Her eyes were wooden and vacant, but a faint spark appeared when she looked at the children, as if seeing a version of herself from thirty years ago.

Zhou Mingri passed her, turned down another street, and stopped in front of "Stirling Bakery."

The owner of the bakery was an elderly woman in her seventies, named Wendyslin. Her hair was completely gray and white, and she always wore a gentle smile. Since Clayen had memories of her, she had been selling bread and pastries here.

Hmm, her Tynemouth pies and lemon cakes were delicious... Zhou Mingri swallowed, smiling and said, "Madam Stirling, one pound eighteen-ounces of rye bread."

"Oh, little Clayen, where's Banse? Not back yet?" Wendyslin asked with a smile.

"Still a few days," Zhou Mingri vaguely replied.

As she portioned out the rye bread, Wendyslin sighed and remarked, "He's such a hardworking young man, he'll find a good wife." Her lips twitched up, showing a playful smile. "Now it's better, you've graduated. You're our History Department graduate from Tynemouth University~ Well, you'll earn your money soon. You shouldn't live in such an apartment. At least you should have your own bathroom."

"Madam Stirling, you look like a young and lively woman today," Zhou Mingri could only respond with a nervous chuckle.

If Clayen could successfully pass the interview and become a lecturer at Tynemouth University, the entire family would indeed be heading towards a comfortable middle-class life!

In his fragmented memories, he had even fantasized about renting a standalone house in a more suburban area, with five or six rooms upstairs, two bathrooms, a large balcony, two rooms downstairs, a dining room, a living room, a kitchen, another bathroom, and a basement storage room.

This wasn't a dream. Even an intern-level lecturer at Tynemouth University earned a weekly salary of two Gold Pounds, and upon full-time employment, it was three Gold Pounds and ten Syllars. Knowing that Clayen's older brother Banse had worked for years and still only earned one Gold Pound and ten Syllars weekly, while ordinary factory workers often earned less than one Pound or just a little more, Zhou Mingri knew that such a house could rent for between nineteen Syllars and one Gold Pound eighteen Syllars.

"This is the difference between earning three or four thousand Syllars monthly versus eleven or twelve thousand Syllars..." Zhou Mingri muttered to himself.

However, all this depended on passing the interview at Tynemouth or Beckland University.

As for other paths, without connections, one couldn't secure a recommendation to become a civil servant, and for someone studying history, the job prospects were even narrower, as private advisors for nobles or bankers and industrial magnates weren't in high demand.

Considering that Clayen's knowledge had turned into "fragments," incomplete and often missing pieces, Zhou Mingri felt a mix of awkwardness and guilt about his expectations for Mrs. Stirling.

"No, I've always been young at heart," Wendyslin humorously replied.

As she weighed out sixteen loaves of rye bread and placed them into Zhou Mingri's large brown paper bag, she held up her right hand and said, "Nine pennies."

Each loaf of rye bread weighed around half a pound, and there was inevitably some variation.

"Nine pennies? Wasn't it eleven pennies just two days ago?" Zhou Mingri asked instinctively.

And the month before that, it was fifteen pennies.

"You should thank the repeal of the **Grain Act** and the people who protested," Wendyslin said with her hands held out, smiling.

Zhou Mingri nodded vaguely, not fully understanding, though his memories of the **Grain Act** were somewhat fragmented. He only remembered that its core was to protect the price of domestic agricultural products, preventing the import of grain and cereal from southern countries like Fenwport, Masquerade, and Lumberg until prices reached a certain level.

Why would people protest against it?

Without saying more, Zhou Mingri was worried about carrying the revolver, so he carefully took out the banknotes, handed one of them to Mrs. Stirling, and put the change—three copper pennies—into his pocket. Then, he carried the bag of bread towards the "Lettuce and Meat" market across the street, determined to get the lamb stew with tender peas his sister had asked for.

At the intersection of Iron Cross Street and the Lilies Street, there was a town square bustling with activity. Numerous tents had been set up, and strange, amusing clowns were handing out flyers everywhere.

"Tomorrow night, circus performance?" Zhou Mingri glanced at the flyers in others' hands and whispered the gist of the content.

Melissa would definitely like it. He wondered how much the tickets would cost. A thought struck him, and he moved closer.

Just as he was about to ask one of the red-and-yellow clowns, a hoarse female voice came from beside him:

"Want a divination?"

Turning his head instinctively, Zhou Mingri saw a woman wearing a pointed hat and a black long skirt standing in front of a low tent. Her face was painted with red and yellow grease, and her eyes were a deep, gray-blue color.

"No," Zhou Mingri shook his head, he didn't have the spare money for divination.

The woman smiled. "My Tarot readings are very accurate."

"Tarot..." Zhou Mingri froze.

This pronunciation was very similar to the Tarot cards on Earth!

And on Earth, Tarot cards were a form of fortune-telling cards, except they had additional 'symbolic figure cards'.

Wait a minute... he suddenly recalled the origin of Tarot divination in this world.

It wasn't derived from the seven orthodox deities, nor was it an ancient relic. Instead, it was invented over one hundred seventy years ago by then-President of the Indis Republic, Rosier Gustav.

This Mr. Rosier invented the steam engine, improved the sailboat, overthrew the rule of the Indis Kingdom, and gained recognition from the Church of the Craftsman God, becoming the first President of the new republic.

Later, he campaigned across the north and south, incorporating countries like Lumberg under his protection, making northern continent powers like the Ruin Kingdom, Fenwport, and Fasack Empire bow to him. He then reformed the republic into an empire, styling himself 'Caesar the Great'.

It was during Rosier's rule that the Church of the Craftsman God received its first public revelation since the Fifth Era, changing the deity's name to the 'God of Steam and Machinery'.

Rosier also invented Tarot divination, establishing the current composition and gameplay of the cards. Among them were several familiar types, like Whist, Hearts, Texas Hold'em, and Quart... 

Additionally, he sent fleets through the storms and chaos to discover a route to the southern continent, opening the era of colonization.

Unfortunately, in his old age, he was betrayed, and in the year 1198 of the Fifth Era, he was assassinated by the Eternal Sun Church, the Solon family of the original Indis royal bloodline, and other nobles, dying in the White Maple Palace.

This... recalling these common facts suddenly made Zhou Mingri feel a toothache.

Could this woman be a fellow traveler from another world?

With that thought, Zhou Mingri decided to take a look at the Tarot cards here. He nodded to the woman wearing the pointed hat and face paint, saying, "If not... well, if the price is reasonable, I'll try."

The woman immediately smiled. "Sir, you're the first person to come for a divination today. It's free."

### Chapter 5: The Ritual

Free? Free things are the most expensive! Zhou Mingrui muttered under his breath, determined to refuse any additional services that might come his way.

If you can't even divine that I'm a time traveler, then what good are your skills?

With that thought, he followed the woman with red and yellow face paint into the low tent, bending down to enter.

Inside, the tent was pitch black, with only a faint bit of light filtering in, barely enough to illuminate a table covered in tarot cards.

The woman, wearing a pointed hat, was completely unfazed. Her black skirt flowed like water around the table as she sat opposite him and lit a candle.

The flickering, dim light cast the tent in shades of light and shadow, instantly adding an air of mystery.

Zhou Mingrui sat down without a sound, his gaze sweeping over the tarot cards on the table. He recognized familiar major arcana cards like The Magician, The Emperor, The Hanged Man, and Temperance.

"Comrade Luoser could really be 'the elder'... I wonder if he's from my home country, the Great Eater Empire..." Zhou Mingrui moved his lips slightly, a dizzying thought crossing his mind.

He hadn’t had time to examine all the cards laid out on the table when the woman, who claimed her divinations were incredibly accurate, already reached out and gathered all the tarot cards together, stacking them into a pile and pushing it toward him.

"You wash and cut the cards," the circus fortune-teller said in a low, hoarse voice.

"I wash them?" Zhou Mingrui asked instinctively.

The fortune-teller’s red and yellow face paint seemed to shift as she revealed a faint smile.

"Of course. Only you can divine your own fate; I’m just an interpreter."

Zhou Mingrui immediately became wary and asked:

"Does that come with an extra charge?"

As a keyboard folklorist, I’ve seen plenty of tricks like this!

The fortune-teller seemed taken aback for a moment before replying grudgingly:

"Free."

He breathed a sigh of relief, tucking his revolver a little deeper into his pocket. Then, with a calm demeanor, he extended his palms and expertly shuffled and cut the cards.

"Okay," he said, placing the shuffled tarot cards in the center of the table.

The fortune-teller clasped her hands together, studying the cards attentively for a moment before speaking:

"Sorry, I forgot to ask. What do you want to divine?"

Back when he was pursuing his unrequited初恋 (初恋), Zhou Mingrui had studied tarot cards. Without hesitation, he replied:

"The past, the present, and the future."

This was a tarot spread where three cards are laid out in sequence, representing the past, present, and future.

The fortune-teller nodded first, then her lips curved upward into a smile.

"That means you need to shuffle the cards again. You have to understand what you’re asking before you can draw cards with meaningful symbolism."

You were playing me earlier... Can’t you be a little generous? Was it really just because I kept emphasizing that it was free?

Zhou Mingrui’s facial muscles twitched slightly. He took a deep breath, retrieved the tarot cards, and reshuffled and cut them once more.

"Should be fine this time," he said, placing the cut cards on the table.

"Done," the fortune-teller said, reaching out to pick up the top card. Her voice grew even lower and huskier as she placed it to his left. "This card represents the past."

"This one represents the present," she said, placing the second card directly in front of him.

She picked up the third card and placed it to his right.

"This one represents the future."

"Alright, which one do you want to see first?" Once she finished, she lifted her head and gazed deeply into Zhou Mingrui’s eyes with her gray-blue irises.

"Let’s start with the present," Zhou Mingrui said after a moment’s thought.

The fortune-teller slowly nodded and turned over the card in front of him.

The card depicted a young man dressed in splendid clothes, wearing an ornate headpiece, carrying a staff over his shoulder, with luggage hanging from the top of the staff. A small dog pulled at his heels. The number "0" was printed on the card.

"The Fool," the fortune-teller whispered, her gray-blue eyes fixed on Zhou Mingrui.

The Fool? Tarot’s zeroth card? A beginning? A start that encompasses all possible beginnings?

Zhou Mingrui, who wasn’t even a beginner in tarot, made a rough interpretation based on his limited knowledge.

Just as the fortune-teller was about to speak, the tent’s canvas door was suddenly thrown open, letting in a harsh sunlight that forced Zhou Mingrui, who was facing away, to instinctively squint.

"You’re impersonating me again! Divination is my job!" a woman’s voice shouted angrily. "Go back! Remember, you’re just a circus animal trainer!"

Zhou Mingrui adjusted to the light and saw another woman standing in the doorway—also wearing a pointed hat, a black skirt, and red and yellow face paint, but taller and thinner.

The woman sitting opposite him stood up, looking displeased.

"Don’t mind me. I just enjoy this kind of thing. I must say, sometimes my divinations and interpretations are quite accurate. Really..."

As she spoke, she raised her skirt and hurriedly walked around the table, disappearing into the tent.

"Sir, would you like me to interpret something for you?" the real fortune-teller asked Zhou Mingrui with a smile.

Zhou Mingrui moved his lips, asking sincerely:

"Free?"

"...No," the real fortune-teller replied.

"Then forget it," Zhou Mingrui said, sliding his hand back into his pocket, pressing the revolver and some coins. He bent down and stepped out of the tent.

This is ridiculous. Finding a circus animal trainer to do tarot divination!

If you’re not a good fortune-teller, can’t you at least be a decent clown?

Zhou Mingrui quickly pushed the incident aside. At the "Lettuce and Meat" market, he bought 1 pound of subpar lamb meat for 7 pence, along with tender peas, cabbage, onions, and potatoes. Adding the bread he’d already bought, the total cost was 25 copper pennies, or 2 shillings and 1 penny.

"Money really doesn’t last long," Zhou Mingrui sighed. "Poor Benson..."

Not only had he spent the two banknotes he’d taken out, but he’d also lost a penny from his pocket.

He casually remarked this and didn’t think much more of it, hurrying back home.

With the main ingredients ready, it was time to perform the ritual for good luck!

...

After the upstairs tenants had all left, Zhou Mingrui didn’t rush to perform the ritual. Instead, he first translated the terms "Fu Sheng Xuan Huang Xian Zun" into ancient Fasak and Runian languages, planning to try the original spell again the next day if it didn’t work.

After all, he had to consider the differences between the two realms and follow local customs.

As for translating it into Hermes language, which was used for ancient prayers and sacrifices, Zhou Mingrui found it difficult due to his limited vocabulary.

Once he finished, he pulled out four black rye loaves from the paper bag. One was placed in the corner where the coal stove used to be. Another was hidden beneath the bottom edge of the wardrobe. The third was tucked into the corner where the closet met the wall. The fourth was placed in a cluttered spot near his desk.

Taking a deep breath, Zhou Mingrui walked to the center of the room. He paused for a few minutes to calm himself before taking a solemn step and walking in a square in a counterclockwise direction.

With his first step, he whispered:

"Fu Sheng Xuan Huang Xian Zun."

With his second step, he sincerely murmured:

"Fu Sheng Xuan Huang Tianjun."

With his third step, he held his breath and whispered:

"Fu Sheng Xuan Huang Shangdi."

With his fourth step, he exhaled and silently recited:

"Fu Sheng Xuan Huang Tianzun."

After returning to his starting point, Zhou Mingrui closed his eyes and waited, hoping for a result. He felt a mix of anticipation, unease, hope, and fear.

Could he go back?

Would the ritual work?

Would something unexpected happen?

The darkness before him seemed to glow with a deep red light. His thoughts raced through his mind, unable to settle.

Just then, he suddenly felt as if the air around him had stopped moving, becoming thick and eerie.

Following this, he heard whispers that were sometimes subtle, sometimes sharp, sometimes ethereal, sometimes tempting, sometimes狂躁 (frantic), sometimes疯狂 (insane). Even though he couldn’t understand the murmurs, he couldn’t help but listen and try to discern their meaning.

His head began to ache violently, as if a steel钎 (钎) had been driven into it.

Zhou Mingrui felt his head would burst. His thoughts were clouded with a hallucinatory haze.

He knew something was wrong. He tried desperately to open his eyes but couldn’t manage even the simplest action.

His body grew increasingly tense, as if it could snap at any moment. A self-mocking thought crossed his mind:

"Don’t provoke trouble if you don’t want to die..."

Unable to endure it any longer, just as the tension in his mind reached its breaking point, the cacophony of voices and whispers faded away, leaving an eerie silence. The atmosphere felt surreal.

Not only the atmosphere, but Zhou Mingrui also felt as if his body had become similarly surreal.

He tried to open his eyes again, and this time, it was effortless.

A swirling gray mist filled his vision,朦胧 (blurry), indistinct, boundless.

"What’s going on?" Zhou Mingrui looked around in astonishment, then lowered his head and saw that he was floating on the edge of an endless gray mist.

The mist flowed like water, dotted with countless deep red "stars." Some were large, some were small, some were hidden deep within, others floating on the surface.

Staring at this holographic-like scene, Zhou Mingrui reached out his right hand, half in confusion, half in exploration, trying to touch one of the deep red "stars" floating on the surface, hoping to find a way to escape.

As his fingers brushed against the surface of the star, ripples erupted from his body, startling the "star" into a burst of light, like a dreamlike firework.

Zhou Mingrui jumped in surprise and hastily withdrew his hand. In the process, he accidentally touched another "star."

That one also flared to life.

Zhou Mingrui felt dizzy and disoriented.

...

In the luxurious villa in the Queen’s Quarter of Beckland, the capital of Runne Kingdom, Audrey Holm sat in front of the dressing table, stroking an ancient, cracked copper mirror on the table.

"Magic mirror, magic mirror, wake up..."

"I command you in the name of the Holm family to awaken!"

...

She tried various phrases, but the mirror remained unresponsive.

After more than ten minutes, she finally gave up, pouting in disappointment and muttering softly:

"Dad was definitely lying to me. He always tells me this mirror is a treasure from the Black Emperor of the ancient Solomon Empire, a remarkable artifact..."

Before her words faded, the copper mirror on the table suddenly emitted a deep red glow, enveloping her instantly.

...

On the Sina Sea, an outdated three-masted ship plowed through a violent storm.

Alger Wilson stood on the deck, his body swaying with the ship’s movements, effortlessly maintaining his balance.

Dressed in a long robe embroidered with lightning patterns, he held a strangely shaped glass bottle. Bubbles occasionally churned inside, frost sometimes condensed into snow, and winds sometimes carved patterns on its surface.

"Still missing ghost shark blood..." Alger murmured.

Just then, a deep red light erupted between the bottle and his hand, instantly engulfing the surrounding area.

...

Above a sea of gray and white mist, Audrey Holm’s vision returned. She looked left and right, both terrified and confused, noticing that the man with a blurred figure beside her was doing the same.

Then, almost simultaneously, they both noticed a mysterious figure standing not far away, surrounded by a grayish-white mist.

Zhou Mingrui was equally stunned.

"Sir, where are we?"

"What do you intend to do?"

Audrey and Alger exchanged surprised glances, falling silent for a moment before speaking in unison.

**Chapter 6: The Extraordinary**

The same Runian language, the same heavy and tense feeling.
Where are we? What am I supposed to do? I wonder too... Zhou Mingrui calmed down and silently repeated the two people's questions.
What struck him most profoundly, however, wasn't the sentences formed by the words, nor the meaning they conveyed, but the panic, vigilance, fear, and awe displayed by the man and the woman!
Being inexplicably pulled into this gray mist world by the two of them, even as the "culprit," Zhou Mingrui himself was unusually shocked and surprised. How much more so for them, the passive party!
In their eyes, this kind of thing, this kind of experience, must have surpassed their wildest imagination, right?
In that instant, Zhou Mingrui thought of two options. One was to pretend to be a victim myself, hide my true identity, and in doing so, gain a certain level of trust to observe the situation calmly and fish for information. The other was to maintain the mysterious and unfathomable image they saw in their eyes, take the initiative in guiding the development of events, and extract valuable information from it.
There was no time for further thought or probing. Zhou Mingrui seized the fleeting idea in his mind and made a swift decision, opting for the second approach.
Leverage their current psychological state and seize the greatest advantage!
A brief silence hung over the gray mist for a few seconds. Zhou Mingrui let out a light laugh, his tone calm and his voice low but not heavy, as if responding to a visitor's polite inquiry:
"A trial."
A trial... A trial? Audrey Hall stared at the enigmatic man obscured by gray and white mist, finding the whole situation absurd, amusing, horrifying, and bizarre.
One moment, she was in her bedroom, standing before her dressing table. The next, she had "arrived" in this place filled with gray mist!
How utterly incomprehensible!
Audrey took a breath, revealing an impeccable, polite smile, and tentatively asked:
"Sir, is the trial over? Can we go back now?"
Algernon Wilson also considered making a similar test, but his extensive experience made him more composed. He suppressed his impulse and simply observed silently.
Zhou Mingrui looked at the questioner. Vaguely, he could discern the outline of the figure before him—a tall girl with soft, golden hair—but her specific features were unclear.
He didn't rush to answer the girl's question. Instead, he turned his gaze to the man on the other side. The man had unruly, sea-foam-like deep blue hair, and a medium build that wasn't particularly robust.
At that moment, Zhou Mingrui suddenly gained a clarity. When I become stronger, or when I understand this gray mist world more deeply, perhaps I will be able to truly see through the obscurity, to clearly perceive the appearance of the girl and the man.
In this incident, they were the guests, and I was the host!
With this shift in mindset, Zhou Mingrui immediately noticed some details he hadn't paid attention to before.
Both the girl with the sweet voice and the man who was calm and reserved appeared quite ethereal, tinged with a faint redness, like the projections of those two deep red "stars" onto the gray mist above.
And this projection was based on the connection between myself and the deep red—a connection that was intangible yet could be truly grasped.
If this connection were severed, the projection would dissipate, and they would return... Zhou Mingrui nodded imperceptibly, turned his gaze to the golden-haired girl, and smiled softly:
"Of course. If you formally request it, I can send you back right now."
Audrey, hearing no malice in his tone, breathed a sigh of relief. Believing that a gentleman capable of such miraculous feats would certainly uphold his promise, she didn't rush to ask for departure.
Instead, her spirits slightly steadied, she found herself not in a hurry to leave. Her emerald eyes darted left and right, sparkling with an unusual light.
She spoke tentatively, yet with excitement and eagerness:
"This has truly been a wondrous experience... Well, I've always looked forward to something like this. I mean, I love the mysterious, the miracles that surpass nature. No, my point is—Sir, what should I do to become an Extraordinary?"
The more she spoke, the more excited she became, even losing coherence in her words. The dream that had germinated from listening to elders' tales of strange legends and bizarre stories in her childhood seemed to finally have a glimmer of hope.
In just a few sentences, she had forgotten the fear and panic that had gripped her moments before.
Good question! I also want to know the answer... Zhou Mingrui self-teased himself.
He began to think about how to respond in order to maintain an air of mystery.
At the same time, he felt that standing here and conversing seemed a bit low-key. In a scene like this, shouldn't there be a temple, a long table, and numerous carved, ancient-patterned, mysteriously feeling backrest chairs, with myself seated at the highest point, quietly observing the guests?
As soon as this thought crossed his mind, the gray mist suddenly churned, startling Audrey and Algernon.
In the blink of an eye, they saw towering stone columns appear around them, and a vast dome overhead.
The entire structure was magnificent, grand, and imposing, as if it were the throne room of a giant from legend.
Beneath the dome, where the gray mist gathered, a bronze long table appeared, with ten high-backed chairs on either side, and similar seats placed in front and behind. On the backs of the chairs, brilliant and subdued reds shimmered, outlining strange constellations that did not correspond with reality.
Audrey and Algernon found themselves seated directly opposite each other, in the positions closest to the head of the table.
The girl glanced left, then right, and couldn't help but mutter under her breath:
"What a marvel..."
Indeed, it was... Zhou Mingrui extended his right hand, lightly stroking the edge of the bronze long table with small, almost imperceptible movements, maintaining a calm facade.
Algernon also took in the surroundings. After a few seconds of silence, he suddenly spoke, answering Audrey's question in Zhou Mingrui's stead:
"You are from Luan, aren't you?"
"To become an Extraordinary, join the Church of the Night Goddess, the Church of the Storm Lord, or the Church of the God of Steam and Machinery."
"Although most people never encounter an Extraordinary in their lifetime, to the point where they might even doubt the churches, and even within the major churches, some clergy share similar doubts, but I can tell you unequivocally: at the Tribunal, the Court of Judgment, the execution agencies, Extraordinary beings still exist, still fighting against the dangers that grow in the darkness. Just not nearly as many as in the early Black Iron Age or before."
Zhou Mingrui listened intently, but his body language deliberately conveyed an air of nonchalance, as if listening to a child's story.
Relying on his residual historical knowledge from Cleric, he knew the "Black Iron Age" referred to the current era, the Fifth Era, which began thirteen hundred forty-nine years ago.
Audrey listened quietly, then sighed and said:
"Sir, I know what you're saying, and even more. For example, the Night's Watch, the Penal Executioners, the Heart of Machinery. But, I don't want to lose my freedom."
Algernon let out a low chuckle, speaking vaguely:
"Is there really no cost to becoming an Extraordinary without considering joining a church, undergoing trials, or seeking out the royal family, noble houses with millennia of history, or perhaps stumbling upon hidden evil organizations?"
Audrey instinctively puffed out her cheeks, then nervously looked left and right. When she was sure the "Mysterious Sir" and the man opposite hadn't noticed her little action, she pressed on:
"Is there really no other way?"
Algernon fell silent. After several breaths, he turned his head to look at the "Mysterious Sir," Zhou Mingrui, who remained silent and observant.
Only after seeing that Zhou Mingrui wasn't objecting did he turn back to Audrey and said, carefully:
"I actually have two Level 9 formulas."
Level 9? Zhou Mingrui murmured to himself.
"Really? Which two?" Audrey clearly knew what Level 9 formulas represented.
Algernon leaned back slightly, answering in a measured tone:
"You know, for humans to become true Extraordinary beings, they can only rely on elixirs. And the names of these elixirs come from the 'Profane Tablets,' having undergone constant translation through Giant, Elven, Ancient Hermes, Ancient Fasak, and Contemporary Hermes languages, evolving long ago to fit the times. The names aren't the key; the key is whether they represent the 'core symbol' of the elixir."
"The Level 9 formulas I have are as follows: one is called 'Sailor.' It grants you exceptional balance, allowing you to walk freely on land even during a stormy ship voyage. You'll also gain extraordinary strength and hidden scales beneath your skin, making you as slippery as a fish, agile in water like a sea creature, able to dive for at least ten minutes without any equipment."
"Sounds amazing... The 'Sea Followers' of the Storm Lord?" Audrey asked, half in expectation, half to confirm.
"In ancient times, it was indeed called 'Sea Followers,'" Algernon said without pausing. "The second Level 9 formula is called 'Audience.' As for what it was called in ancient times, I don't know. This elixir grants you outstanding mental acuity and sharp observational skills. You've probably seen operas and plays, so you understand what 'Audience' means—it means observing like a spectator, examining the 'actors' in secular society, discerning their true thoughts from their expressions, their manners, their speech quirks, their unseen actions."
As he spoke, Algernon emphasized:
"You must remember, whether in lavish banquets or bustling streets, the audience is always just the audience."
Audrey's eyes lit up. It took her a while to speak:
"Why? Well, that's a follow-up question. I... I've grown fond of this feeling, 'Audience.' How do I obtain the formula for 'Audience'? What do I trade for it?"
Algernon, as if prepared, spoke in a low voice:
"One hundred milliliters of Ghost Shark blood."
Audrey nodded excitedly first, then worriedly asked:

"The name you can call me is The Fool."

The brief answer dissipated within the grand temple and the弥漫的雾气, but in Audrey and Argyle's hearts, that voice echoed for a long time, creating ripple after ripple.

Unexpected, yet it felt right. The name perfectly embodied mystery, power, and strangeness!

"Respected Mr. Fool, may I rashly request your permission to ask if you could serve as a witness to our transaction?"

"A small matter," Zhou Mingrui thought rapidly, answering in a manner befitting his identity.

"It is an honor, Mr. Fool," Argyle also stood up, placed his right hand over his chest, bowed his head, and paid respects.

Zhou Mingrui lightly pressed his right hand, smiled, and opened his mouth:

"You continue."

Argyle nodded, sat back down, and looked at Audrey:

"If you can obtain the Ghost Shark's blood, find someone to deliver it to the 'Brave and Sea' bar in Pelican Street, White Rose District, Port Priz, and tell the owner Williams that this is something 'Captain' wants."

"Once I confirm, will you send me the address to mail the potion recipe, or shall I tell you directly here?"

"I choose the more confidential way. Here, although it tests my memory quite a bit."

"Mr. Fool, would you mind having more such 'experiments'?"

"Mr. Fool, don't you find this kind of 'gathering' quite interesting? Although your power surpasses our imagination, there are always fields you don't know or aren't good at. That lady over there clearly comes from noble lineage, and I myself have my own experiences, knowledge, channels, and resources. Perhaps between us, we could help you accomplish some trivial tasks that are inconvenient for you to handle yourself in the future."

"Determined! My designation is 'Justice'!"

"Suspenders."

"Suspenders, could you repeat the address, please? I'm afraid my memory isn't sharp enough."

"No problem," Argyle was quite satisfied with Audrey's seriousness and repeated the address.

After默念了三次, Audrey said cheerfully again:

"I heard that the Tarot was actually a game invented by Emperor Rosier, and it doesn't actually have divination capabilities?"

It's just that ordinary people can't perceive this, let alone interpret the 'hints' they receive. When they use divination tools, these pieces of information are presented through the tools. A simple example is dreams and dream interpretation," Argyle glanced at Zhou Mingrui, saw he didn't object, and then spoke to disprove Audrey's statement. "The Tarot actually belongs to this category of tools. It uses more symbolism and reasonable elements to help us conveniently and accurately interpret the 'hints'."

Zhou Mingrui seemed to be daydreaming, but he was listening very attentively. However, his spiritual disconnection began to worsen, and his head started to ache in spasms.

"Understood," Audrey nodded in agreement, then emphasized, "I didn't mean that. I'm not questioning the Tarot. I heard that Emperor Rosier actually created another deck, a secret one, made of cards symbolizing certain unknown forces, totaling twenty-two cards. After completing that, he referred to it to invent the twenty-two Major Arcana cards of the Tarot as a game tool. Is this accurate?"

She looked at Zhou Mingrui, seemingly wanting to get an answer from the mysterious Mr. Fool.

Zhou Mingrui just smiled and didn't open his mouth, his gaze shifting towards "Suspenders," as if to quiz him.

Argyle instinctively straightened his back and said in a low voice:

"Twenty-two divine paths..." Audrey repeated with a tone full of admiration.

"Alright, today's gathering will end here," he decided immediately, speaking in a low voice.

"Obey your will," Argyle bowed his head in respect.

"Obey your will," Audrey imitated "Suspenders."

"Let's look forward to the next gathering."

The Scarlet Star dimmed, the red light like water receded back. Just as Audrey and Argyle heard Mr. Fool's words, his figure became increasingly blurred and ethereal.

In less than a second, the "projection" shattered, and silence returned to the gray mist.

Zhou Mingrui felt himself quickly becoming heavier, his surroundings fading away. First, darkness, then brilliant sunlight.

"Dream-like... What exactly is that gray mist world... And who or what kind of power created that change just now... " Zhou Mingrui muttered to himself, full of confusion. His legs felt as heavy as lead as he walked towards the desk.

He picked up the watch he had placed outside earlier, checking how much time had passed.

"A 1:1 time flow rate," Zhou Mingrui roughly estimated.

He put down the watch. With the intense headache, he could no longer hold on and sat down in the chair, lowering his head and using his left thumb and index finger to massage both sides of his temples.

After a long time, he suddenly sighed, speaking in Chinese:

"It seems I can't return anytime soon..."

The ignorant can be fearless, but after witnessing such incredible things and learning about the extraordinary realm and mysterious world, Zhou Mingrui dared not rashly attempt the "转运仪式" (transmigration ritual) in Old Fasack and Ruin languages anymore!

Who knew what other situations might arise, perhaps even stranger and more terrifying, even life-altering!

"At least I need to master esoteric knowledge thoroughly before attempting it," Zhou Mingrui thought helplessly.

Fortunately, the so-called "gathering" could provide him with help.

"From now on, I am克莱恩 (Cai Lian)."

...

Next week, perhaps he could overhear the potion recipe for the "Audience"... 

That "gathering" just now was truly amazing. People from different parts of the world, turning thousands of miles into mere steps, face-to-face communication, mutual exchange... Huh, this sounded familiar...

"Let's get to know some online dating platforms?"
